entry.title: “We are doing everything we can to boost small businesses and...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“We are doing everything we can to boost small businesses and help them through the winter months ahead until we have a vaccine and Congress passes additional relief. Cultural venues, artists and minority-owned businesses have been disproportionately impacted by this pandemic. This assistance will help the small businesses that have been hit hardest so that they don’t permanently shutter,” said bill sponsor Rep. Leslie Herod, D-Denver."

Denver7

Colorado lawmakers passed 10 bills in the three-day 2020 special session that adjourned Wednesday which allocate around $300 million in relief spending toward small business, housing, child care and other sectors deeply affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

thedenverchannel.com

Colorado lawmakers pass 10 bills aimed at COVID-19 pandemic relief in 2020 special session

Colorado lawmakers passed 10 bills in the three-day 2020 special session that adjourned Wednesday which allocate around $300 million in relief spending toward small business, housing, child care and other sectors deeply affected by the coronavirus pandemic.Colorado lawmakers passed 10 bills in the three-day 2020 special session that adjourned Wednesday which allocate around $300 million in relief spending toward small business, housing, child care and other sectors deeply affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

entry.title: “If you are not complying with public health orders and you...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“If you are not complying with public health orders and you are staying open, you don’t get to get the money that these small businesses who have shut down, who are at 10% capacity,” said Rep. Leslie Herod, D-Denver, one of the bill’s sponsors. “You don’t qualify. You’re doing fine. You’re open. If you are doing everything to comply, you need help.”

The Daily Sentinel of Grand Junction

The Colorado Legislature completed three days of a rare special session spurred by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic on Wednesday, passing 10 bills aimed at helping small businesses, improving child care

entry.title: “Caring for Denver and its partners designed this funding to...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Caring for Denver and its partners designed this funding to meet people where they are and create impactful community solutions. Each funded organization is led either by persons with lived experience related to mental health and substance misuse or by members of the community the organization serves. Community members who will use these supports will inform or co-create each funded organization’s activities and services to ensure it works for them.”

entry.title: “Herod said she was grateful for the opportunity to serve...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Herod said she was grateful for the opportunity to serve again.

“I look forward to continuing to lead our charge of fiercely advocating for, and representing, our Black communities here in Colorado," she said in a statement. "Together, our Black Caucus will continue to be a force to reckon with in the Capitol.

“We’ve seen the numbers and we’ve heard the stories. The Black community in Colorado needs equitable relief from the COVID-19 pandemic, immediately. Additionally, we m...ust address the systemic inequities that have only been exacerbated by this deadly pandemic. Together, we can create a Colorado that works for all of us.”

Colorado Politics

entry.title: “We know that we have to have the administration to get it...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“We know that we have to have the administration to get it out, but we want you all to know this money is coming,” said Herod. “Our goal is to make sure you can come back and have a chance at recovery. Don’t shutter yet.”

CBS4 Local

A bill that would provide $57 million in aid for small businesses could be on Gov. Jared Polis' desk by tomorrow.

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Want to join our team? We are hiring! Send your resume and cover letter to outreach@leslieherod.com to apply. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis, so apply quickly!

entry.title: "The one-time payment to out-of-work Coloradans —...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The one-time payment to out-of-work Coloradans — expected to arrive in the coming days — is part of a $1.3 billion stimulus package the governor has proposed to help citizens. In the three-day session, the Democratic-led General Assembly will consider only the most pressing spending items — totaling up to $300 million — but more action is expected during the next regular session in early 2021."

The Colorado Sun

The question surrounding the special Colorado legislative session is whether the stimulus plan can even make a difference given its meager size.

coloradosun.com

Colorado lawmakers reconvene to consider stimulus plan, but experts question the cost to the state

The question surrounding the special Colorado legislative session is whether the stimulus plan can even make a difference given its meager size.The question surrounding the special Colorado legislative session is whether the stimulus plan can even make a difference given its meager size.

entry.title: Small businesses all around Colorado continue to struggle to...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Small businesses all around Colorado continue to struggle to stay open at severe capacity restrictions. This means facing extraordinary difficulties to pay their staff and rent. With Congress refusing to act, we are taking action to provide immediate relief. Today our small business relief bill passed through the House Finance Committee.

The bill has four major components:

(1) $8.65 million for licensing fee relief for restaurants and bars through the Department of Revenue ...and the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment.

(2) $37 million for direct aid payments to eligible small businesses in eligible counties with severe capacity restrictions including restaurants, caterers, fitness and recreational sports centers, and movie-theaters.

(3) $7.5 million for grants to arts and culture orgs & independent artists through Colorado Creative Industries.

(4) $4 million for the Minority Business Office Strategic Fund to provide direct relief, grants and loans, and technical assistance to minority-owned businesses.

See More

entry.title: "One of the biggest reasons we’ve heard that cities do...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"One of the biggest reasons we’ve heard that cities do these processes is to put more power into our historically marginalized communities,” said Kiki Turner, a spokesperson for the Denver Department of Finance. “We all know that the city has frequent flyers to the city council, to community meetings, and that’s great. But this is really about trying to reach the people who likely need improvements most and aren’t able to show up or, you know, have their voice be heard at that meeting.”

The Hancock administration has set aside $1.7 million for participatory budgeting, or “PB,” as government types call it. After years of pushing from City Councilwomen Robin Kniech and Candi CdeBaca and other activists, Denverites will get to decide how to spend that cash during a public process next year."

Denverite

Denverites are getting a $1.7 million allowanceThe city’s foray into “participatory budgeting” comes with caveats and criticism. Also, hopes and dreams about housing and civic engagement.Denverites are getting a $1.7 million allowanceThe city’s foray into “participatory budgeting” comes with caveats and criticism. Also, hopes and dreams about housing and civic engagement.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: "Until Tuesday, claims against the police department had...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Until Tuesday, claims against the police department had been trickling in since the violent protests of this summer. One man claimed the police blinded him, for example. Another man claimed an officer violated him with a baton in his anus.

The stack of claims comes ahead of a lengthy report, expected to be released in December, by the Office of the Independent Monitor on the department’s response to protests."

Denverite

Attorneys hint at massive lawsuit against Denver for police department’s response to summer protestsThe City Attorney’s Office received 51 claims Tuesday.Attorneys hint at massive lawsuit against Denver for police department’s response to summer protestsThe City Attorney’s Office received 51 claims Tuesday.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: "The legislation, much of it bipartisan, includes direct...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The legislation, much of it bipartisan, includes direct payments to small businesses, tax forgiveness, grants for child care centers and money to expand broadband access.

The aid, which is constrained by the state’s budget, totals about $200 million and is aimed at providing a bridge until a much larger congressional stimulus measure is approved. Lawmakers concede that the money isn’t a silver bullet, and business leaders say it’s unlikely to revive businesses that are at the edge of demise."

The Colorado Sun

Democrats, who are in the majority, are prioritizing eight bills for the lawmaking term that begins Monday. The aid totals about $200 million, with an additional $100 million to help Colorado's public health response.

coloradosun.com

Colorado Democrats unveil details of their coronavirus relief plans for the special legislative session

Democrats, who are in the majority, are prioritizing eight bills for the lawmaking term that begins Monday. The aid totals about $200 million, with an additional $100 million to help Colorado's public health response.Democrats, who are in the majority, are prioritizing eight bills for the lawmaking term that begins Monday. The aid totals about $200 million, with an additional $100 million to help Colorado's public health response.

entry.title: "Senators Faith Winter, D-Westminster, and Kevin Priola,...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Senators Faith Winter, D-Westminster, and Kevin Priola, R-Henderson, along with Representative Leslie Herod, D-Denver, will sponsor a bill providing $57 million in assistance for businesses affected by capacity restrictions aimed at reducing the spread of coronavirus.

“There will be a process set up to ensure that the money can get out the door as fast as possible to go to the communities that are most in need,” Senate Majority Leader Steve Fenberg, D-Boulder, said."

Denver Westword

The special session starts November 30.

westword.com

Colorado Lawmakers Outline COVID-Relief Proposals for Special Session

The special session starts November 30.The special session starts November 30.

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The Colorado General Assembly plans to take up eight bills focused on COVID-19 relief for families and businesses in the special session that begins Monday.”

9NEWS (KUSA)

The Colorado General Assembly plans to take up legislation to help families and small businesses in the session that starts Monday.

entry.title: “It’s a conversation playing out across Colorado. At least...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“It’s a conversation playing out across Colorado. At least 60,000 people, including Hull, face the expiration of unemployment benefits by the end of December. Others are bracing to lose their jobs again as climbing caseloads and new restrictions threaten to shut down retail and restaurant businesses.

And, this time, there’s no real hope that the federal government will intervene with another major stimulus package — at least for now. That means there is no longer a $600-a-week unemployment boost, no Paycheck Protection Program, no new federal aid to states and no stimulus checks in the near future.”

Colorado Public Radio

Colorado’s legislature will meet in a special session this week to craft a kind of miniature stimulus package worth $200 million to $400 million.

cpr.org

Unemployment And Housing Benefits Are Expiring. Colorado Will Try To Stop The Bleeding With A Modest Stimulus

Colorado’s legislature will meet in a special session this week to craft a kind of miniature stimulus package worth $200 million to $400 million.Colorado’s legislature will meet in a special session this week to craft a kind of miniature stimulus package worth $200 million to $400 million.

entry.title: “Responding to all this won't require Biden to rewrite...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Responding to all this won't require Biden to rewrite the economic plans he'd already developed, because of who they were always intended to help.
"The agenda was really crafted with the core insight in mind that a lot of people have been left behind for a long time," noted longtime Biden economic adviser Jared Bernstein.”

CNN

Sitting in an Iowa diner a year ago, candidate Joe Biden aimed his economic agenda at the widening gap between America's rich and everyone else.

entry.title: “So Denver is trying something new. It asked a...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“So Denver is trying something new. It asked a homeless-service provider, the Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, to build a team comprised or a nurse and four outreach workers, including one person who has experienced homelessness, whose sole job will be to work with residents of large encampments (those with more than a half-dozen tents).”

Denverite

entry.title: “I think it’s important for all allies to realize that small...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“I think it’s important for all allies to realize that small businesses are really a huge part of our economy, and just supporting us – even past the pandemic, past this crazy hear we’ve had, would be really great to get everyone on an even playing field,” she said.
“Generally speaking, minority businesses are some of the smallest owned businesses, and we do not get access to the funding that a lot of other business owners get,” Guzman Taylor said. “Ours, in particular, did not get access to funding available at the beginning of this pandemic.”

9NEWS (KUSA)

This summer, Black-owned businesses saw a rush of new support as the country’s focus turned to racial justice. They hope that continues into the holiday season.

entry.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.
